metadata.titleEn: Globally glacier meltwater hydrochemistry and chemical weathering data set
metadata.description: This dataset includes the mean concentrations of major soluble cations (Na+, K+, Mg2+, and Ca2+) and total dissolved solids (TDS) in meltwaters draining 92 glaciers, as well as glacier location, specific discharge, the distance of sampling sites from glacier terminal, sampling time, filter type and pore size; the hourly concentrations of major cations in 19 glacial basins within Asia; the mineral composition of glacial sediments from 5 glacial basins within Asia; the daily cation concentration, daily cation flux, daily cation denudation rate (CDR), daily cation denudation intensity (CDI) and daily TDS concentration, as well as daily temperature, daily precipitation, daily runoff and daily specific discharge in 5 glacial basins within Asia; the cationic concentration, cationic flux, CDR and CDI from 51 glacial basins globally, as well as the basin location, basin area, annual temperature, annual precipitation, specific discharge, glacier coverage, glacier elevation and glacier slope; the cation concentrations, cation fluxes, CDR, CDI and TDS concentrations from global glaciers, Greenland ice Sheet, Antarctic ice sheet, 19 glacial regions around the world and 19 mountain ranges within Asia, as well as glacier area, glacial runoff, specific discharge, annual temperature and annual precipitation. This dataset is derived from hour-by-hour monitoring of 19 glaciers within Asia and day-by-day monitoring of 5 glaciers within Asia by the dataset provider, published data at home and abroad, and privately shared data by the authors with the dataset provider. This dataset can be used to study the relationship between glacier changes and physical erosion, chemical weathering, and climate evolution, and to assess the potential impact of glacier and ice sheet ablation on the element cycle, carbon dioxide budget, and the climate system.

Quantification.Question: What is the total number of glacier meltwater samples collected globally for measuring major soluble cations and total dissolved solids?

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for measuring ion concentrations in glacier runoff differ between high-frequency hourly monitoring and daily monitoring across different glacier regions?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for ion concentrations in glacier runoff include high-frequency hourly monitoring for 19 glacier basins in High Asia and daily monitoring for 5 glacier basins in the same region. These methods differ in temporal resolution, with hourly monitoring providing more detailed temporal data compared to daily monitoring. Both approaches involve collecting data on major soluble cations and total dissolved solids, but the hourly method allows for capturing more immediate changes in ion concentrations and can be more sensitive to short-term environmental fluctuations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on understanding climate systems if data on cation flux, chemical denudation rate, and TDS concentration from ice sheets and glaciers are integrated into broader climate models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: By integrating data on cation flux, chemical denudation rate, and TDS concentration from ice sheets and glaciers into broader climate models, researchers could better evaluate the potential impacts of glacier and ice sheet melting on element cycling, carbon dioxide balance, and climate systems. This integration could enhance the understanding of the relationships between glacier changes, physical erosion, chemical weathering, and climate evolution.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect detailed data on ionic concentrations and chemical weathering in glacier watersheds worldwide?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objective of collecting detailed data on ionic concentrations and chemical weathering in glacier watersheds is to study the relationship between glacier changes and processes like physical erosion, chemical weathering, and climate evolution. Additionally, such data are crucial for assessing the potential impacts of glacier and ice cap melt on element cycles, carbon dioxide budgets, and the climate system.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures and instruments are commonly used to collect and analyze glacier runoff samples for understanding chemical weathering processes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves monitoring glacier runoff samples for soluble cations (Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+) and total dissolved solids (TDS). It includes measuring average concentrations across global glacier basins and requires noting glacier location, runoff depth, sample distance from the glacier terminus, sampling time, filter type, and pore size. This process is supported by hourly and daily monitoring in certain regions, allowing for analysis of ion concentrations, fluxes, and chemical denudation rates (CDR), alongside environmental factors like temperature, precipitation, and runoff.
